We did go snorkeling once, but the fish weren't that colorful and the coral reef was pretty damaged. Not that impressive, if you ask me.

Despite all that, we still managed to have a good time. We met some other travelers at the bar and had a few drinks together. They were nice enough, but we didn't really click. Looking back, I'm not really sure why I bothered going to Hawaii. It wasn't like it was life-changing or anything. But hey, it was a decent way to spend a week, I guess.

I've always been fascinated by the lives of my friends who seem to have it all together. They're all settled into stable careers, with decent paychecks and benefits, and they get to enjoy the finer things in life - nice cars, fancy apartments, and exotic vacations. Meanwhile, I'm over here scrambling to make ends meet as a freelancer, constantly juggling multiple projects just to keep a roof over my head.

It's hard not to feel like I'm failing when I see them posting pictures of their luxurious weekend getaways on social media, while I'm stuck at home working on my laptop, trying to meet a looming deadline. Their success seems effortless, like they're coasting through life on autopilot. And don't even get me started on their salaries - I mean, seriously, how do they afford those designer clothes and expensive dinners? It's like they're living in a different world.

Sometimes I wonder if they're even happy, or if they're just pretending to be something they're not. Do they ever feel anxious about paying their bills, or worried that they'll lose their job tomorrow? Or are they just blissfully unaware of the struggles that come with making a living?

I know I'm not alone in feeling this way - there are plenty of other freelancers out there who are struggling to make ends meet. But it's hard not to compare myself to them, to feel like I'm somehow less worthy because I'm not where they are. Maybe I am just jealous, but it's hard not to feel like I'm falling behind, like I'll never catch up.

As I look around at my friends' seemingly perfect lives, I start to wonder if I'm just deluding myself. Am I really cut out for this freelance thing, or am I just fooling myself? The thought sends a shiver down my spine, and I find myself questioning everything I thought I knew about myself.
